Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation2: An external auditor has just requested specific financial statements for an immediate review.
Story: My phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Will you call tonight? Dad wants to hear your voice.” It’s Thursday, our usual call night, and I know how much these weekly chats mean to them. They wait for my updates, ask about my health, and share little stories from home. But as I glance at my computer screen, my heart sinks. The external auditor’s email sits at the top of my inbox, marked urgent. They need the quarterly financial statements by tomorrow morning, and I haven’t even started reconciling the accounts. My manager expects nothing less than perfection—no errors, no delays. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in: the warmth of my parents’ voices on the other end of the line, the cold precision of spreadsheets demanding my attention. My hands hover over the keyboard, torn between dialing home and diving into numbers, my mind racing with guilt and anxiety as I wrestle with which role to honor first.
